name: Richmond, VA
tagline: Former capital of the Confederacy reinventing itself as a foodie haven with complex history

diversity.summary: RECKONING AND INTEGRATING: Richmond was the capital of the Confederacy, and that weight is real. But the city is actively transforming — Monument Avenue's Confederate statues were removed, and younger residents are building genuinely integrated communities. The Fan, Carytown, Scott's Addition, and Church Hill have real cross-racial mixing, especially among younger demographics. However, deep historical segregation patterns persist in many neighborhoods. Richmond has a large Black population (~46% city) but residential integration varies dramatically block by block. An interracial couple would be comfortable in the progressive urban core but would encounter the legacy of segregation in neighborhood patterns. The integration is genuine where it exists but the city is still mid-journey.
diversity.diversity_index: ~45% White, 46% Black, 7% Hispanic — nearly equal but historically segregated; integration improving in urban core
diversity.notable: Former Confederate capital actively reckoning with history; integrated urban neighborhoods emerging; interracial couples comfortable in Fan/Carytown; legacy segregation patterns still visible

safety.summary: Crime varies significantly by neighborhood. Some areas (East End, parts of South Side) have higher crime, while The Fan, Museum District, and West End are quite safe. Overall feels safer than many East Coast cities. Improving but still has pockets of concern.

scenery.summary: James River runs through the city with parks and trails along it. Historic architecture, tree-lined streets in older neighborhoods. Rolling hills, Fall colors are beautiful. Not dramatic mountains but pleasant urban greenery. 2 hours to Blue Ridge Mountains.

climate.summary: Four distinct seasons with manageable winters—some snow but not brutal. Hot, humid summers balanced by beautiful spring (cherry blossoms) and fall. More seasonal variation than Charlotte, less extreme than Denver. Good for those who want real seasons without harsh cold.

culture.summary: Richmond has become a surprising food destination—multiple James Beard nominees, thriving brewery scene (Stone Brewing HQ), indie music, arts. The VCU (Virginia Commonwealth University) presence adds youth and creativity. Strong sense of place with complex history. Feels authentic, gritty, artistic—not corporate.

pros: Extremely affordable—great bang for your buck
Thriving food and brewery scene (punches above its weight)
Four real seasons with beautiful fall
Smaller city feel with urban amenities
Strong Black community and cultural presence
cons: Complicated racial history that's still present (Confederate monuments debate)
Smaller than other options (may feel limited after 1-2 years)
Less polished/more gritty than some prefer
Job market smaller (though growing in tech/healthcare)
saturday: You wake up in The Fan to Victorian rowhouse charm and walk to Lamplighter Coffee for pour-overs and a breakfast sandwich. The morning is spent strolling Carytown—vintage shops, quirky boutiques, a mile of independent businesses that feel authentic, not manufactured. Lunch at Stella's brings Greek lemon chicken soup and spanakopita, then you bike the James River Park trails, stopping to watch kayakers navigate the rapids. By evening, you're at the South of the James Farmers Market, then dinner at L'Opossum (fine dining with a sense of humor). You end the night at a Scott's Addition brewery, surrounded by VCU students and young creatives. Richmond feels scrappy, artistic, and deeply itself.

food_scene.summary: Richmond has quietly become a food destination—James Beard semifinalists, a massive brewery scene (Stone Brewing East Coast HQ), and chefs doing creative things without the pretense of bigger cities. The cost-to-quality ratio is exceptional.
farmers_markets: South of the James Farmers Market (year-round, Saturdays)
17th Street Farmers Market (Shockoe Bottom, Saturdays seasonal)
food_scene.food_culture: Richmond's food culture blends Southern tradition (fried chicken, pimento cheese) with James Beard-level ambition (The Roosevelt, L'Opossum, Lehja Indian). The brewery scene is massive—Triple Crossing, The Veil, Hardywood—and the city has a thriving vegan scene. It's affordable, creative, and unpretentious.
food_scene.grocery_quality: Whole Foods, Trader Joe's, Ellwood Thompson's Local Market (beloved local grocer), Publix. Solid access, though fewer specialty international markets than larger metros.

neighborhoods.name: The Fan District
neighborhoods.vibe: Historic Victorian rowhouses, tree-lined, artsy, walkable
neighborhoods.diversity_notes: Mixed, progressive, VCU students and young professionals
neighborhoods.why_for_them: Walkable, affordable, beautiful architecture. Great local cafes and shops. Safe and characterful. Best value in Richmond.

neighborhoods.name: Carytown
neighborhoods.vibe: Richmond's 'Mile of Style'—quirky shops, restaurants, vintage stores
neighborhoods.why_for_them: Independent businesses, walkable, unique character. Great for exploring. Feels like a neighborhood with soul.

neighborhoods.name: Scott's Addition
neighborhoods.vibe: Former industrial area turned brewery/arts district
neighborhoods.why_for_them: Trendy, lots of breweries and new development. Walkable. Good for Josh's adventurous side. Can feel gentrified.

neighborhoods.name: Museum District
neighborhoods.vibe: Residential, tree-lined, near VMFA (art museum) and VCU
neighborhoods.why_for_them: Safe, walkable, beautiful streets. Cultural amenities nearby. Quieter than Fan but still urban. Great quality of life.

neighborhoods.name: Church Hill
neighborhoods.vibe: Historic hilltop neighborhood with views—gentrifying rapidly
neighborhoods.diversity_notes: Historically Black, now mixed as gentrification progresses
neighborhoods.why_for_them: Affordable, historic charm, great views. BUT gentrification tensions and safety varies by block. Mixed recommendation.
